criteria: Experimental Design: The student designs a controlled experiment to test the mixing of substances, identifying variables and controls effectively.
Data Collection: The student accurately collects and records data during the investigation.
Analysis and Interpretation: The student analyzes the data and draws appropriate conclusions about whether new substances were formed.
Cause and Effect Reasoning: The student identifies and explains cause-and-effect relationships in the mixing of substances.
descriptions: No attempt to design an experiment or the design lacks any controls.
The experimental design is missing key elements, such as a control or clearly defined variables.
The experimental design is rudimentary, with some attempt to control variables, but lacks detail.
The experimental design is adequate, with identified variables and controls, but could be improved for clarity.
The experimental design is well-thought-out, clearly identifying variables and controls to ensure a fair test.
The experimental design is comprehensive and sophisticated, demonstrating a deep understanding of experimental controls and variables, ensuring a robust investigation.
No data is collected or the data is completely inaccurate.
Data collection is minimal or contains significant inaccuracies.
Data is collected inconsistently, with some errors or omissions.
Data is collected adequately, with minor errors or omissions.
Data is collected accurately and completely, with clear and organized records.
Data is collected meticulously and comprehensively, with detailed and well-organized records that facilitate analysis.
No attempt to analyze the data or draw conclusions.
Analysis is missing or the conclusions are not supported by the data.
Analysis is superficial, and the conclusions are weakly supported by the data.
Analysis is adequate, and the conclusions are generally supported by the data.
Analysis is thorough, and the conclusions are clearly supported by the data, with reasonable explanations.
Analysis is insightful, and the conclusions are strongly supported by the data, demonstrating a deep understanding of the chemical processes involved.
No cause-and-effect relationships are identified.
Attempts to identify cause-and-effect relationships are incorrect or irrelevant.
Cause-and-effect relationships are identified but not clearly explained.
Cause-and-effect relationships are identified and explained adequately.
Cause-and-effect relationships are identified and explained clearly, demonstrating a good understanding.
Cause-and-effect relationships are identified and explained insightfully, demonstrating a comprehensive understanding of the underlying principles.
